statement.text: AAA surveillance involves periodic imaging to monitor aneurysm growth and determine optimal timing for intervention. Guidelines recommend imaging intervals based on diameter: 3.0-3.9 cm every 3 years, 4.0-4.9 cm annually, and 5.0-5.4 cm every 6 months. Rapid growth (≥0.5 cm/6 months or ≥1 cm/year) warrants expedited intervention regardless of diameter.
statement.formal: AAA Surveillance: <4cm q3yr, 4-4.9cm q12mo, 5-5.4cm q6mo; Rapid growth (≥0.5cm/6mo) = intervention threshold

explanation.intuition: Managing a small AAA is like watching a slow-growing tumor - the goal is to act before it becomes dangerous while avoiding unnecessary surgery. Since small aneurysms rarely rupture but larger ones have increasing risk, we increase monitoring frequency as the aneurysm grows. We want to catch the 'inflection point' where benefits of repair outweigh risks.
explanation.key_insight: The threshold for intervention (5.5 cm in men, 5.0 cm in women) is chosen because the annual rupture risk at these sizes begins to exceed the operative mortality. Surveillance allows personalization - a fast-growing 4.5 cm AAA may warrant earlier repair than a stable 5.0 cm AAA.
explanation.technical_details: Ultrasound is the preferred modality for surveillance of small AAAs due to low cost, no radiation, and reproducibility. CT is indicated when nearing intervention threshold or if ultrasound is limited. Measurements should be consistent (same modality, same measurement technique) across time. Growth rate calculation requires at least 6-12 months between measurements to minimize measurement error impact.
common_misconceptions: All AAAs require CT surveillance - ultrasound is sufficient for most small aneurysms
Diameter is the only factor - growth rate and symptoms also guide timing
Male and female thresholds are the same - women have 5.0 cm threshold due to higher rupture risk
Once stable, surveillance can stop - lifelong monitoring is recommended

definitions_glossary.surveillance: Regular monitoring with imaging to track aneurysm behavior over time
definitions_glossary.growth_rate: Change in maximal diameter over time, usually expressed as cm/year
definitions_glossary.intervention_threshold: Size or growth rate at which repair benefits outweigh risks

risk_factor_modification.smoking_cessation: May slow growth rate; essential for all patients
risk_factor_modification.blood_pressure_control: Target BP <130/80, may reduce wall stress
risk_factor_modification.statin_therapy: May slow progression; recommended for cardiovascular risk
risk_factor_modification.beta_blockers: No proven benefit for AAA growth specifically

special_populations.women: Earlier intervention threshold (5.0 cm) due to 3-4x higher rupture risk at any given size
special_populations.connective_tissue_disorders: Earlier intervention (4.5-5.0 cm) for Marfan, Loeys-Dietz, EDS Type IV
special_populations.family_history: May warrant earlier intervention in first-degree relative with AAA rupture

definition.@value: Standardized imaging intervals for monitoring AAA growth and determining intervention timing

sources.citation: Chaikof EL, et al. SVS practice guidelines for AAA. J Vasc Surg. 2018
Wanhainen A, et al. ESVS Clinical Practice Guidelines for AAA. Eur J Vasc Endovasc Surg. 2019

learning_objectives: Apply appropriate surveillance intervals based on AAA diameter
Recognize triggers for accelerated surveillance or intervention
clinical_pearls: Use the same imaging modality for serial measurements to minimize variability
Women have ~4x higher rupture risk at any given diameter - earlier threshold
Rapid growth is as important as absolute size
Smoking cessation is the only lifestyle intervention proven to slow AAA growth

medicalCode.description: Ultrasound, B-scan and/or real time for abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) screening
